items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The weather forecast this morning, 27 September 2023, is mostly dry, with some light rainfall possible this afternoon. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River levels have now fallen at the Far Sawrey gauge, so the flood alert has been removed.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels continue to remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water.   Further rain is expected later today, which will keep the levels high, but we are not expecting to see any significant changes.  

Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00am on 28/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from The Rumps to Hartland Point excluding Bude
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday evening. High water at Padstow is at 4.43pm, flooding is possible 1 hour either side of high tide. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
Storm Agnes is forecast to bring strong force 8 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 4m which could cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be up to 550mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
The communities most at risk include Port Quin, Port Isaac, Port Gaverne, and Boscastle.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care near the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this information by midday on Thursday.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 4.76 mAOD, this is 0.55 metres above astronomical tide level.
Further flood alerts and warnings are expected to be issued this weekend associated with the largest astronomical tides of the year.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday evening. High water at Ilfracombe is at 5.25pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 7, south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 3m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be around 580mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 4.79 mAOD, this is 0.6 metres above astronomical tide level.
